sub_topic: Probability of a certain type of consumer behavior occurring in a market
message_1: A certain supermarket chain conducted a survey and found that 30% of their customers buy organic products. The supermarket also found that 20% of their customers are vegetarian. If 10% of the customers are both organic buyers and vegetarian, what is the probability that a randomly selected customer is either an organic buyer or a vegetarian?
message_2:
To find the probability that a randomly selected customer is either an organic buyer or a vegetarian, we can use the formula for the probability of the union of two events:

P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A ∩ B)

where A represents the event of being an organic buyer, B represents the event of being a vegetarian, and A ∩ B represents the event of being both an organic buyer and a vegetarian.

We are given the following probabilities:
P(A) = 0.30 (30% of customers buy organic products)
P(B) = 0.20 (20% of customers are vegetarian)
P(A ∩ B) = 0.10 (10% of customers are both organic buyers and vegetarian)

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

P(A ∪ B) = 0.30 + 0.20 - 0.10
P(A ∪ B) = 0.40

So, the probability that a randomly selected customer is either an organic buyer or a vegetarian is 40%.
